text:
Love, love LOVE Seafood Sally's! Met a friend for lunch there and immediately fell for the restaurant's charm and peaceful vibe. 

We started with a 1/2 dozen oysters and some onion rings. The oysters were absolutely scrumptious and the onions rings were battered and fried to a crunchy perfection. 

We of course had to try the sautÃ©ed crab fingers and Matty's Shrimp Dip. I'll be honest the crab fingers were not my favorite I found them overly rich. Matty's Shrimp Dip however is utterly divine! Serious, it was creamy, balance in its flavor profile and just the right amount of shrimp for texture.  

As our main we decided to split the Captain's Platter and I love me some cornmeal fried goodness. The oysters, cat fish and shrimp were great but the star for me were the hush puppies could eat plates of those all by myself. 

Almost  forgot, the cocktails are great too. I had the Pirate Queen it's great for sipping during our hot southern days. 

The staff is amazing everyone was friendly and it's wonderful to see so much diversity within their Krewe.
name: Seafood Sally's

text:
After walking quite a way on a warm afternoon, my family and I were looking for a light lunch and cool refreshing drinks. We found Frenchmen All Day and eagerly went inside for a reprieve from the sun. 

The menu is modest-they don't try to do more than they can do well, and I appreciate that. Service was a little more laid back than I would have preferred...we never got refills on our waters, and being as thirsty as we were, we pulled out our own water from our backpack to refill our glasses ourselves.

The food was good-between us, we enjoyed a Cuban sandwich, the chicken salad sandwich and a traditional American breakfast. Everything was tasty.
name: Frenchmen All Day

text:
I'm just your basic Nola girl who loves pizza sold by the slice so I won't contribute to the century long debate of "true NY style pizza" -- though it certainly sounds like it is from the other reviews. 

For me, it's the convenience of being able to order a slice when you want a snack or a couple slices when you've had a bad day and just need the comfort of carbs. I've only had the pepperoni and the mooz? (the white cheese slice); my +1 had the regular cheese. It's all fantastic and they've got a decent selections of soda/beer/water to wash it all down with. 

I gotta comment on the quality control. One of the employees (manager, I suppose) chucked two slices of the square slices because maybe they'd been sitting out too long? Idk, I would've eaten them... but 'preciate these guys' commitment to serving us fresh slices!

Love the $1 packets the Mike's Hot Honey is sold in. I haven't tried the drizzle on any of Paulie Gee's slices but I think it's probably best paired on a cheese slice -- the pepperoni doesn't need it in my opinion. 

I went back twice in one day so needless to say, I'll be back again!
name: Paulie Gee's Crescent City Slice Shop

text:
Let me start by saying this review is not about the servers. Our waitress was very nice. 
This is about the food, or I should say lack of it as we never got to try it. After placing our order for 2 breakfast sandwiches, we waited as we would expect. After 10 minutes - nothing. All they had to do was cook the egg as the croissant was already made.  Our waitress asked the cook how much longer for our food and he said he hadn't gotten around to it. We were the only customers in there - what exactly was he waiting for? I recognize we was prepping food for the day but it seems like common sense that he would have set that aside and then taken care of the customers in front of him who are waiting. I will not frequent a place that cannot prioritize guests over other tasks. I should add there were multiple people in the kitchen so that makes me even madder. We walked out and will not be back even though we live in the area.
name: Frenchmen All Day

text:
Man, this pizza is amazing.  And the place gives a healthy nostalgic nod to the early 80's with accent pieces from that era.  But back to the pizza.  I've been there a couple times for the classic slice of pepperoni - perfect crisp crust, and the pepperoni has a nice zing and cups up leaving that delicious, spicy meat nectar in the cup.  Tables forego Parm in place of garlic powder.  You can get a packet of spicy honey if that's your sort of thing.  I tried it, it's ok, dozens of better applications than pizza IMHO.  

Anyway, so today was the first time trying the Freddie Pepp, which is their Freddie Prinze but with the addition of Pepperoni.

RUN, don't walk and get yourself a slice of the Freddie Pepp.

First, what is it?  It's kind of like one of those Detroit styles, with a focaccia-esque dough.  But what they do is put cheese down on the crust, so when it bakes, you get this crispy cheese underneath.  Then the nice pillowy dough, then the most amazing pizza sauce you'll ever have, then GOBS OF CHEESE, then that zippy Pepperoni.

If I'm gonna die, I hope it's with the taste of that slice on my tongue.
name: Paulie Gee's Crescent City Slice Shop

text: The crawfish appetizer is to die for!! I'd order that for my meal all day long! The crab dip app was very different. Most of our table very much enjoyed it, I personally wasn't a fan. Our table of 4 also ordered a seafood boil platter, crawfish x2, shrimp and crabs, added 2 orders of potatoes and corn. It was good but we didn't know what to do with the crawfish and our waitress had no clue either. Someone did end up coming to our table to show us what to do. The restaurant is VERY LOUD!! We sat in the front room and could barely talk to each other.
name: Seafood Sally's

text: Stopped by for late lunch and enjoyed a robust chop chop (or "TChoup tchoup") Salad filled with salami and Swiss cheese  and a  tangy vinaigrette, yummy pimento cheese  with toast triangles, and a delicious oat latte and a mocha. The key lime pie was outstanding for dessert! The chef and server were kind and attentive and they accommodated our desire to sit at the cute mint-colored tables we put together on the shaded sidewalk. Look forward to returning to try boozy coffee drinks!
name: Frenchmen All Day

text:
Wow!

I love the way this place is trying to give off a late 70's early 80s pizza place vibe. Really gets you into the mode to eat some delicious pizza!

Speaking of which, the slices were off the chain! The pepperoni slice was delightful but that Freddys pepperoni slice was every bit the reason you should go. It's like a huge Sicilian/Detroit style slice and it was amazing! I can't wait to order more slices and pizza from here. Please, please go give this place a try and make sure they become the local pizza joint it intends to be.
name: Paulie Gee's Crescent City Slice Shop

text: Fantastic cafe and bar. Such a lovely addition to the neighborhood. Easy seating, friendly staff, excellent cocktails, delicious food, great hours. Came here multiple times over the course of a long weekend at all hours, and had consistently great service. Good latte (with soy and oat milk too). Love the breakfast croissant, quiche, and red beans and rice. Favorite cocktails were the Baby Come Back and Hey Sailor. Indoor and outdoor seating, never had to wait. Perf location for brunch, or dinner and coffee and a cocktail before a night out! Don't sleep on this one!
name: Frenchmen All Day

text: We stumbled upon this place while visiting from Seattle.  The food was amazing, a special shout out to the the spoon bread Benedict served in a cast iron skillet.  The staff was very friendly and service was great.  Great coffee, creative adult beverages, nice decor and just great food done well.

text:
Great addition to the Frenchman/Marigny Triangle dining scene!  Friendly service.  Excellent cup of coffee.  Great breakfast options.  Very good cinnamon roll.  Not the super gooey type, but perfect with coffee.  

Shrimp & grits are awesome.  I'm not much of an egg guy, but the spoonbread Benedict is a must-try for those of you who are.  Looking forward to trying something from the lunch or dinner menu next time! 

Super casual vibe, inside or on the sidewalk.

text:
This is some definitely tasty pizza, probably some of the best in New Orleans. At 7 locations in the States now, this is a small time chain that is relatively new to New Orleans. The price point is about average or higher for higher-end pizza (23-33 USD/pizza; 3.50-4.75/ slice). The price per slice can be high, but they are rather worth getting if you are in that area. Definitely, the staff are noteworthy. They are so friendly, and I have been surprised by an extra slice when I got back to work before. Because I work in the CBD, I may find this pizza more worthwhile because of the accessibility. You might not because finding a parking spot in the city can be a straight pain. 

If you are standing by the shop right now teetering between going in or not, do it. It's worth your time. If you are chilling on your couch, looking for a quick quality slice, Reginelli's or Theo's might be your stop.
name: Paulie Gee's Crescent City Slice Shop

text:
Absolutely love this pizzeria! It was so good I had to turn around and go back in for another slice of the Hellboy. It was something about the thin sliced pepperoni pizza with hot honey drizzled on it that took my breath away. 
I've gone at least 3x's and have enjoyed the pizza each time.

attributes.Ambience: {u'divey': None, u'hipster': None, u'casual': True, u'touristy': None, u'trendy': None, u'intimate': None, u'romantic': None, u'classy': None, u'upscale': None}

text: Boy did the city need this!  Good pizza is hard to come by in the Big Easy, finding a good slice, well you'll have an easier time finding a unicorn. Enter Paulie Gee's. Having deep roots in New York, the business brings a true New York style pizza and focaccia to NOLA. Slices are big and fresh of both the pie and focaccia. It's obvious they do not skimp on the pepperonis or the cheese as all are properly covered. The sauce isn't a side note, rather it is deep and rich with the right flavors one should expect from good pizza. The crust is crispy and holds the toppings with no dreadful pizza "flop". You can hold it and fold it as a slice is supposed to be enjoyed.  Now the prices are even better with an average of $4.50 per slice!!  Two slices and you can leave as an honorary Italian!!!
name: Paulie Gee's Crescent City Slice Shop

attributes.BusinessParking: {u'valet': False, u'garage': True, u'street': None, u'lot': None, u'validated': None}
attributes.Ambience: {u'divey': None, u'hipster': None, u'casual': True, u'touristy': None, u'trendy': None, u'intimate': None, u'romantic': None, u'classy': None, u'upscale': None}

text:
I give credit where credit is due so I'll start off by saying the onion rings and the Turkey necks (according to another in my household) were very good.  Each get a star to be fair. However my compliments and stars  stop there. 

To start with, we ordered pick up via toast and among our orders was an order of boiled peanuts.  When the person coming to my home to dine with us arrived after picking it up, the peanuts were missing.  I called and spoke with the person I ultimately learned was the general manager of the establishment, I was told "oh, we no longer carry those."   That was it. No apology. So after I was taken aback I could order something and pay for something they no longer carry, I began to inquire about options.  I could either drive back halfway across town for "something else" or drive halfway across town to get a $7 refund which couldn't be done over the phone.  The GM was essentially unapologetic for the circumstances and kind of aggressive.  That part of my experience assured this was probably my lone experience with the place.  Then we ate. 

One dish was the oyster salad that was simply anemic and way overpriced.  You can get twice the quality at half the price at many local upscale places.  The real kicked was the $30 "seafood bucket" which consisted of two blue crab and 8 16-20 count shrimp along with two pieces of corn and three small potatoes all swimming in about an inch or so of butter at the bottom of a bucket that was about 1/3 full.  The lid and the outside were all soaked with greasy fingerprints and the spice was "inconsistent" to say the least.  All in all it was a laughably overpriced meal.  If you look at my reviews I very rarely take to this medium to review bad meals because I think restaurants should get a few shots to get things right with me.  This place isn't getting their second shot after the poor experience.  There are plenty of places three folks can spend this kind of money for a much better meal.  Seafood in NOLA?  There are standards, Sally.
name: Seafood Sally's

text:
A great place to hang out and grab a cup of Joe. The interior and exterior are both freshly redone and offers a historic and quaint interior. I had an almond milk latte which was good  and husband had a tasty cold brew mocha coffee. What my review rating is really Gor was the homemade yogurt bowl. Unfortunately my phone died so I was not able to snap a photo but if you enjoy raspberry, strawberry and granola you should try. I will be back and will update with photo. 
The barista said the cinnamon rolls are baked in house and they looked amazing. So hopefully I will have a chance to update my review on the those as well.

attributes.BusinessParking: {u'valet': False, u'garage': False, u'street': None, u'lot': None, u'validated': False}

categories: Gastropubs, Cafes, Nightlife, Breakfast & Brunch, Coffee & Tea, Food, Restaurants, Bars

text:
Big prices Small portions! The bar was Interesting, the disappearing Bloody Mary Mix and no Tonic water. I was told that there wasn't Bloody Mary Mix, so I asked for a Vodka Tonic-No Tonic-But wait we did find the Bloody Mary mix so all is saved.  It appears that the back of the house staff is very competent.  They have figured out how to boil water, and use a fryer, make rice and have mastered the concept of small portions, and high prices.  Being a native of New Orleans-I'm really not used to paying $3.00 per shrimp-I.E. 6 shrimp in a shrimp cocktail for $18.00- no shredded lettuce, just 1 lemon wedge and a minuscule Ramekin of cocktail sauce, loving thrown together in a yard sale glass bowl.  Speaking of fine china-all of the small plates that they used seemed to come from the .25  table at a yard sale .  I also was impressed at the lack of Salt and Pepper shakers on the table-How Upscale and Chic.; though the food could of been better seasoned, and the crab listed in the ingredients, was not discernible in both the dishes that were ordered. So other than the food being lackluster and no where worth the prices charged, it was OK.
HOWEVER- in tiny writing on the bottom of the menu, I was informed that a 3% service charge/extra tax was to be levied to support the health and mental health wellness of the staff.  Frankly it is not the amount, but the concept that makes me not want to return .  First of all they are not my employees.  I would think that the employer, in a forward, looking and progressive manner would be happy to donate 3% of THEIR earnings to insure that their most valuable resource-their Employees are properly cared for.  I wonder if any of the funds-the 3% are kept separate and not comingled .  It would be terrible if by mistake that employee wellness fund be used to possibly pay the bank credit card fee.--Last but not least-I think in order to create a tax-that has to be done by either-Local, or state, or federal individual  ad is done via vote.  Maybe I'm mistaken but don't think a private citizen can legally levee an arbitrary tax.- So go to Seafood Sally's-it's just like Bourbon Street-You will get screwed just as well and the parking is better.

Thanks Chef R
name: Seafood Sally's

text:
I have to say the pizza holds up very well for delivery the two times I've had it delivered via Doordash. Whether it's by the slice or the whole pi it's a great slice. Ordering it by the pie is delivered a lot neater including an old school pizza topper to protect the toppings from getting smushed. If you simply order a few slices to-go be prepared they might stick to each other since nothing is really separating the slices.

Def try their pepperoni with the signature Mike's hot honey. Paulie Gee's uses the smaller pepperonis which I really enjoy.

I'm really excited and looking forward to trying them in-person to get the whole feel!
name: Paulie Gee's Crescent City Slice Shop

text: Yay!! Finally! A decent pizza-by-the-slice spot in NOLA! (Or pizza in general spot, tbh lol.) I stopped in on the Friday of the first week and it was LIT in there. So, pizza wise: loved it!!! I had both the traditional large pepperoni slice and also the thick crust square-shaped Hellboy, and both were great! The Hellboy had this sweet/spicy sauce; I'm more of a savory person when it comes to pizza so I'll probably move forward with the pep only, but the thick crust was crispy on the outside and soft n fluffy on the inside..if you're a pineapple pizza type person, go for it! Operations wise: they have a little bit of work to do. It was pretty packed in there but I still thought it took a bit long (maybe 30 min) for me to get two slices. The guys in there were working super hard, so I'm sure they'll figure out how to manage those high-influx crowds. They have a "call out the name" order pick-up system and it's not super efficient; it was loud in there and people could barely hear their names. Also, they only have bottled drinks and by the time I got there, they were out of bottled water. Again, this was about 5 days in, so I think they still deserved all 5 stars overall. Hoping they continue to be successful and tweak things operationally for efficiency (and, therefore, customer satisfaction) purposes. But it's great! So happy to have them in the city. (Just hoping they extend their hours far beyond 7pm! A girl be needing copious amounts of carbs after a night out in them NOLA streets.)
name: Paulie Gee's Crescent City Slice Shop

Our next app was the bbq crab claws holy cow that sauce was amazing.
The hush puppies were yum with the dipping sauce. Loved my shrimp and turkey neck but small and very pricey. Great service super hip vibe but I worry what they will thrive off of once crawfish boiled season is over :/ also super small outdoor tables we had food on side chairs ?!

text:
They really let me down. I hosted a dinner for 5 for some people who have done something nice for me to thank them. We had drinks, appetizers and then put our dinner order in. 45 min later our waiter said our order was not in - by accident- and we were nice and said we would take the check for the appetizers. Then - five minutes later he brought our order that "wasn't put in" in a bag and says it was "on them". We asked "can't we just eat it here? And the answer was "no."
The bill came - I got the bill for everything- drinks, apps and the food in a bag- except two desserts they threw in the bag that we didn't order and our waiter came over with shots for us we didn't order (one of my guests is sober so that was embarrassing.) I tipped because I felt maybe the waiter would get in trouble and he was a nice guy...But, I did call the manager after dinner. I was given no explanation. A $300.00 dinner disaster. I explained how embarrassed I was. I think we should have been refunded for the main courses we ordered- then was told it wasn't put in- then we said we didn't need it- then was brought to us in a to-go bag, I was taking people out to dinner - not getting them food to go. Never again...I was trying to thank people and I couldn't tell you how mortified I was....
name: Seafood Sally's

text: THE ABSOLUTE BEST BOILED SEAFOOD  IN DA CITY! Seafood Sally's has the cutest decor. The inside reminds you of a beachfront diner. I had the the boiled crawfish and crawfish that were tossed in this seasoning of herbs, garlic, loads of cilantro and other spices. You're literally gonna want to spread that sauce on everything it's that delicious. Cool vibes, the best staff FOH & BOH, beautiful location with easy parking options and FANTASTIC food. What more can you ask for.

text:
Covid, supply chain issues and labor shortages are a real problem for restaurants and I've heavily taken that into consideration with this review. 

Being served undercooked (pink and gelatinous) catfish, waiting over 20 minutes for a canned Sprite to be brought over and watching four tables seated after us get served and leave before our table got our food was just bad restaurant management and execution. 

Plates were brought out at infrequent times, items were missing and we'd go 20 minutes without seeing our server. 

The manager offered a free dessert due to the wait but at that point (2 hours later) we felt more like hostages than patrons. 

The only reason I stayed was because my girlfriend's parents were with us and I didn't want to cause any scene. I also spoke with the manager about the condition of the fish away from the table as some had already been served catfish and I was hoping theirs was cooked. 

Two generous stars because I respect the hell out of the restaurant industry and the workers who make dining out an option for others. 

I wish them better luck and execution in the future.
name: Seafood Sally's

text:
Interesting new seafood spot from the people behind Marji's Grill (which I'm a huge fan of). I went for dinner recently and it was a very mixed experience.

The service was attentive on the front end but on the back end it was a mess. None of the items arrived at the same time or in any predictable order. It seems like the oyster station got backed up and this caused a lot of confusion. We had people walk by our table 3 separate times asking if an order was ours. We didn't get the ordered shrimp cocktail until we were almost done with our meal.

The food was hit or miss. The crawfish tails (far from a mound) were fairly bland and the main note was oil - in fact at the end of the meal the bottom of the dish had congealed. The oysters were EXCELLENT - large and flavorful. Some of the best in town. I got the catch of the day as my entrÃ©e (amberjack, blackened) and it was sadly quite unflavorful. Points to them for it not tasting too fishy but also not great that it didn't taste like any kind of actual spice. The boiled shrimp were excellent although not for the faint of stomach. 

A note of caution on the cocktails - I got the Hemingway daquiri which is not a cocktail known to be spicy. Mine certainly was. I pointed this out to the waitress and got a fresh one and it too was spicy. I resigned myself to drinking it but I think what's going on is that they have a cocktail called "the boil" that uses boil spice and it lingers in the shakers and bar equipment. Which is to say unless you plan to order that cocktail I'd stick to the beer/wine. 

Hopefully with time the service kinks get worked out. This place has a lot of potential and it's nice to see a modern take on a classic New Orleans restaurant archetype - the seafood spot. The menu is currently a little uneven and it's hard to say how much of that is greenhorn staffing and how much is poor chef planning. I have high hopes that on my next visit I'll be blown away.
name: Seafood Sally's

text:
My hotel package included a $50 certificate here, so I went with my sister for dinner.  We ordered the Caesar salad, fried catfish with shrimp and grits, veggie pasta, and the seven layer cake.

The salad was grilled and included fried cheese.  I didn't like the cheese.  It was burnt and salty.  Otherwise, the rest of the salad was good.  I really liked the catfish with the shrimp and grits.  The catfish was fried perfectly and there was a lot of shrimp in all sizes.  The grits were good.  There were some cold pieces, but otherwise it was delicious.

The hostess recommended the seven layer cake, and I'm glad she did because it was delicious.  It was light with just the right sweetness.

Though we enjoyed our meal, my sister and I discussed that there isn't a singular dish that sets Roux apart.  I believe if this restaurant had a signature dish, there would be more people dining here.
name: Roux on Orleans

text: I had a great experience at this restaurant last Friday.  The ambiance is relaxing, not too formal, and nicely lit.  The maitre d was very friendly and helped get everyone seated along with serving the first drinks ordered.  My friend and I ordered a glass of La Crema Pinot Noir and it tasted a little dated.  It wasn't terrible enough for me to ask questions but the maitre d returned and he said he tasted it.  He said it did not taste up to par and he opened another bottle and poured fresh glasses.  It tasted perfect.  I ate an incredible lobster and gouda crepe appetizer (I heard this is one of the chef's specialities).  It tasted light and tasty while it did not leave me starving.  I ate a wonderful entree of a pasta jambalaya.  It was a good sized serving with shrimp, chicken, sausage, mushrooms, and penne pasta.  The chef, Guy Sockrider, exited the kitchen to check on us to make sure that we were enjoying his dishes.  He was extremely sincere and polite.  I was too full to order a desert but I saw the well made dishes my friends ordered including a chocolate mouse cake and creme brulee with berries.  I will return to this restaurant as many times as I can while living in this city.  It's pricy but you definitely get more than your money's worth.
name: Roux on Orleans

text:
I dined here last night with several other yelpers, and although the service was very attentive, I thought the food was below par (although two dishes stood out a very good though). 

First we were brought some lagniappe - it was crab, and avocado, with mango and fish sauce. Fish sauce should not be applied to the subtle flavor that is blue crab.

Next I was brought what they referred to as crawfish bisque. The soup was good, but crawfish bisque it was not, and I felt a bit mislead. Rather it had dairy, and no stuffed crawfish heads.

I tried a crawfish crepe that someone else had ordered and it had a good flavor, but the crawfish tails had a black color and chewiness that indicates they had been frozen. Frozen crawfish tails are typically imported from Asia, and I find that to be an inexcusable crime.

I had an appetizer of the Shrimp Absinthe. This is where things began to head downhill. The sauces had no taste whatsoever of fennel, wormwood, anise, or even licorice. The shrimp tasted nothing like any local shrimp I've ever had. Perhaps they were overcooked, because they were fibrous and even maybe crunch. Plus they were too large.

My entree was the pecan crusted puppy drum with a lemon-butter sauce. I will be to the point here - this fish was not fresh. It tasted as if it sat on the dock for a few days before it was refrigerated. It was not even edible. Furthermore the particular lemon butter sauce was a beurre-blanc, when any chef who's been to a few days of culinary school would learn that a beurre-noisette would be the sauce to serve on fish when nuts are present, as it has a complimentary flavor and aroma. The restaurant was more than courteous enough to not charge for this dish. 

My wife dined on a very dry pork chop before being given a rather bland piece of bread pudding (please just add some Mexican vanilla and cook it until the outside has a crust) with a very thin white chocolate sauce. Another in our group ordered the crÃ¨me brule, which I got to taste, and was very good. It redeemed the restaurant for some of its crimes, but the expired fish was certainly unforgivable.

I suggest the restaurant staff spends some time dining at Antoine's and Galatoire's so that they know what the cuisine they intend to serve should taste like.
name: Roux on Orleans

text:
This place is all right.  I went there the other day with my BFF and we got 1) red beans and rice with sausage, 2) shrimp fried rice, and 3) a grilled chicken sandwich.

The chicken sandwich was big and she wolfed it down.  The red beans and rice were good, and even though I normally don't eat meat, for some reason I decided to get them with sausage (you can get them without).  It tasted kind of odd, but I really do think that's just because I'm not used to eating meat.  But they were good.  I saved the sausage for my friend, and she ate it and enjoyed it.  The shrimp fried rice was fine.  Not bad, not great, just greasy shrimp fried rice.  I don't recommend this place if you're craving greasy, cheap, a-ok Chinese--go to Red Apple on Franklin for that.  But this place is great for sandwiches and sides and po-boys, quick and cheap and easy.  Oh and it's a small grocery with beer.
name: Frenchmen Grocery & Deli

text:
Seeing as though we stayed at the hotel that this place is attached to, it was very convenient for our breakfasts (and breakfast is all we ever had here, we ate it 3 mornings). 

We had really been looking forward to a menu item that we found online called Lost Bread which was a sort of pan perdue, but once we arrived we were told that they did not have it on the menu currently. Instead, they offered a small menu of about 6 items plus a "breakfast buffet" every morning that had an egg dish, hash browns, bacon, sausage, some kind of bread like waffles or biscuits and gravy, plus fresh fruit and things like bagels and croissants. 

My husband just got the buffet all three mornings (about $15) and I got it twice, but the last time I got the breakfast wrap. 

The food was really no more than average, and had it not been so convenient, we probably wouldn't have gone baqck after the first time. However, we were going on a lot of early morning adventures, so it was nice to have a restaurant right at the hotel where we could grab a quick bite. The place was NEVER crowded for breakfast or dinner....in fact, I'm not sure what kind of a business they really do. 

The service was generally good. The waitresses were both incredibly friendly, but a bit spacey at times, especially on our last morning there. 

If I stayed at the hotel again, I would probably treat this restaurant the exact same way...as a convenient place for breakfast, but I wouldn't necessarily seek it out if I didn't stay there again.
name: Roux on Orleans

text: We had breakfast here for 4 mornings as vouchers wee included as part of our hotel stay at Bourbon Orleans.  The vouchers say you can only get the Classic Breakfast--which we did for 2 days and then they let us pick others items which was nice.  The Classic Breakfast is 2 eggs any style (I did scrambled with a little cheese), meat (both the andouille sausage and applewood smoked bacon are yummy), grits or breakfast potatoes (both average) and toast...a lot for most people! All beverages were included--coffee, tea, oj, and soda.  Plenty of butter and jelly on the table.  Our third morning I got the pancakes with both mixed berries and butter pecan syrup--yumm-o!!  The last morning we used the vouchers for the buffet with both hot and cold items.  Food was tasty every morning and the servers are very friendly and attentive especially yemi another gal.  A lot of food and good taste means we probably would eat here again even if not included :)
name: Roux on Orleans

text: Every time I've come in here, the clerks have been awesome. text:
First of all- The Staff.... THESE WAITRESSES ROCK!!! they are so friendly, fast, accurate and on point!! The know what they are doing and they do it well and that makes such a big difference! 
Second- everything I ate there was delicious! I have ate here many times (on westbank expressway) and all the food was always on point! Delicious food at very reasonable price! 
And last The DOUGHNUTS!!! Did I say YUUUUUM!!!! Man,
I wish we had a joes cafe in Mississippi! I would never go to Krispy Kreme again lol!!! The doughnuts are delicious!!! I can't wait to run back over to get some more!!! Yum yum !

text:
I've been there or gotten delivery a handful of times through Waitr. It's a typical diner, so don't expect a five-star experience. The food I've had has been pretty good, and the donuts are great (try the buttermilk drops or maple bacon log). 

I would advise against ordering takeout/delivery, because every time I've done so, the order has been wrong. Every time. Example: a patty melt with no cheese and/or no onions (it's supposed to automatically come with both...what's melting when there's no cheese?), ask for pickles only and you get lettuce and tomatoes (say what?), you receive a waffle with no syrup (hmmm), etc. Through Waitr, I've started paying extra to add items that are supposed to included in the basic item price (and are explicitly included in the item description), because I know they'll leave them off if I don't. I don't intend to get delivery again for that reason. It just doesn't make sense. 

So, go there and enjoy! That way, if something is missing from your order, you can get it remedied without paying an arm and a leg. (P.S. Yes, I know these are all first-world problems, but I'm letting you know, so you can be cautious when appropriate. Go forth and be kind.)
name: Joe's Cafe

text: This could be a 4 star restaurant if the service was faster, the bread was better and the food was served hot on warmed plates.  I waited 20 minutes for the grocery store rolls and another 20 for room temp gumbo followed by perfectly cooked catfish with yummy shrimp dumped on room temp grits on an ice cold plate.  The cold was catching and about 1/2 of the fish was cold in no time.  I complained to the waitress and she apologized but didn't offer a solution other than a new meal.  I didn't want to wait another 40 minutes so I declined.  But a warmed plate with hot grits would have done it.  How hard is that?
name: Roux on Orleans

text: Great food and great service! Chef Roxanne prepared a very special dinner for myself and two friends that joined me. The servers were cheerful and attentive. I had the corn and crab soup which was really tasty but the crab meat salad was the best. My friends enjoyed the Redfish and the chicken dish. Desserts were wonderful. We shared everything! Cream brulllie , bread pudding and chocolate cake with coffee was a perfect way to wrap up this experience. Be aware to enter via the hotel lobby of the Bourbon Orleans Hotel. The sign for Roux is over a door that looks like an entrance but it does not function as such. I had to pull on a couple of doors before I figured this out but I am glad I did.
name: Roux on Orleans

text: On Frenchmen St. listening to live Jazz. Stopped in afterwards for something cold to drink. The Pork Belly Bahn Mi was incredible tasting, fast, and inexpensive. Went back this evening just to eat there again. Had another Bahn Mi and some boudin balls with some of their "house" hot sauce. We are in New Orleans for live music and good food and this little place ranks up there with some of our best dining experiences of the trip.

text: Had the buffet while staying at the bourbon orleans hotel.  Buffet was pricey in my opinion (as i don't think i was hungry enough to eat $21 worth) but overall the quality of the food was worth it. Eggs, french toast, bacon, fruit, pastries, yogurt parfaits, among other stuff! The menu itself had some good options which you could also order from during buffet times which is great! Would recommend this place!

text: I was visiting NOLA for Jazzfest and was staying in Marigny.  Found this place on Frenchmen, kind of a dumpy grocery store.  They had the stuff I needed at OK prices (higher than chain stores but you pay for convenience).  My big surprise, the deli was awesome.  Ordered a breakfast sandwich with eggs/bacon on toast - huge for the price and very fresh.  The food options are cheaper and better than a cafe down the block.  Go figure.  A lot of local traffic goes in and out of this place, most people were picking up food to go.
name: Frenchmen Grocery & Deli

text:
Disclaimer: This review is ONLY for the beignets.

I wouldn't have discover the best beignet in Nola if I didn't stay at the Bourbon Orlean Hotel where this restaurant is located in. My friends ordered their first beignet from here waiting for me to get ready. By the time I met them at the restaurant they ordered seconds for me. I had my share of beignet since this is the second time I been to Nola but this beignet was none like others, its light and fluffy with a touch of the powder sugar. It almost melts in your mouth when it eaten fresh. Its not heavy or dense like the other beignet I tried. I would go back there for the beignets if i visit again.
name: Roux on Orleans

Stayed at the hotel and ate our first breakfast here. The beignets were a major disapontment. I had never had beignets before and they seemed overcooked, what was worse was they were dripping in grease, actually  dripping, there was a 3/16 inch inch pool of grease in the plate.

Server was pleasant and helpful, surroundings nice, clean overall but  beignets, which should be a high point for a restaurant in New Orleans, were terrible.

text: I stayed here for Mardi Gras and it was a great value for its buck, so one morning when everyone was hung over I went down for breakfast myself. Had the steak and eggs it was really good but the food took 25mins to come! I was so drunk from the mimosas I barely made back to the right room! The food was good my waitress was a clown and attentive but they lost a star, simply because the food took so long. It was a classy sit down place and was cheaper then I expected. They are popular for their breakfast buffet.

text:
This is the better of the two "grocery stores" within a few minutes of my house. I put quotations around it because they magically never have what I need, but I still leave with a bunch of stuff. I prefer it over the other mart on Esplanade (less of a creep factor, more ice cream)

I can't vouch for their deli, but it appears to be delicious, as there is a line out the door some days. 

This little cramped grocery store has most things that you could need between shopping trips to the big grocery stores. TP, ice cream, cold drinks, chips, and miscellaneous hangover cures are all over the place. I would recommend this place if you have a snack attack, but not if you need to complete a recipe or get a lot of stuff.
name: Frenchmen Grocery & Deli

text: Oh joes , how I love you but this dine in experience was very interesting . It was a Saturday night and it was about 12 and we went to get donuts but decided to have some food well we ordered the staff was really nice . But it took very long the waitress then later explained after another customer told her off about how long it was taking , which It was long but the waitress said there was a large call out order that was holding up their kitchen . So I don't blame this on the staff I blame this on management/owner . The evening on a weekend seem to need more help or turn down call In orders , your customers who walk in to eat are ur first priority. I felt bad for the staff . So because they were rushed our food was all messed up but the waitress did all she could to fix . I had chicken strips which were good and they had good ranch very tasty , my husband had a burger he said it was good but it seemed to be lacking a little . I love their donuts so we will come back I may just try something diff from the kitchen !
name: Joe's Cafe

text:
I work on Frenchmen St, so I eat here practically every day. It's sooo cheap and sooo delicious. The po-boys are especially good, as well as the chicken/seafood platters & french fries. The fried rice is okay but tastes better with hot sauce. They have quite a wide variety of beverages for such a small place. Another plus is the credit card minimum is only $5.

It is a tiny, cramped place, so best to call ahead rather than wait in line. I was quite impressed that I was able to pick-up 2 shrimp po-boys on Mardi Gras Day, 15 minutes after I called in the order, with a line out the door.
name: Frenchmen Grocery & Deli

text:
A local chain with so-so food but fantastic service.

Joe's is a good choice when you're outside of the French Quarter and nothing else is open. All that to say that it's food that tastes best when you are probably intoxicated.

We had a donut, Cajun egg rolls, and the Philly Cheesesteak Omelet. Cajun eggrolls when fresh and hot are definitely a winner. The Cheesesteak omelet was pretty unappealing with dried, thin slices of meat and congealed cheese product on top. 

The star of the show was definitely the sweet waitress working. All good vibes and big heart with the guests. Chances for a 5-star visit are higher if you show up intoxicated and hungry. (Uber, don't drive drunk, please!)
name: Joe's Cafe

text: #NOLAtourism #foodtourism #chifoodie This review is a 4 for service and a two for food.  We went for the prix fixe Thanksgiving meal.  The price was incredibly resonable and the champagne was generous and free flowing.  The first course of butternut squash soup was delicious.  The rest was only ok.  I don't remember my salad.  My stuffing was filled with sausage so I didn't eat it.  My turkey was served with gravy on it although I asked and was given the impression that it would not be.  I believe the turkey was tasty and moist-- but the gravy was so distracting I cannot be sure.  I would have appreciated the opportunity to put the gravy on myself.  The dessert choices-- both cheesecake-- one pumpkin and the other sweet potato or was it pecan?  In any case all of us who ordered the pumpkin (including me) were underwhelmed.  Those that ordered the other option were satisified.   The best part-- the service and the atmosphere.  The hotel is beautiful.  The location in the French Quarter was perfect for a tourist family like us.  Our server was a young musician, who is in graduate school for hotel management and his training showed every step of the way.  He was polite and attentive.  He connected with every guest ranging from 6yrs old to 80+.  Would we go back?  Not for the food, but I would sit in the bar and enjoy the service and the hotel.
name: Roux on Orleans

text: It's a carry out for to go booze, cigars, and chips... or is it? In true New Orleans fashion this little spot serves food in the back. No lie, this was some of the best butterfly shrimp of my life... in a carry out, on an old wooden stool, next to cases of energy drinks and empty boxes. For 12$ we had a PILE of shrimp and fries. Nothing on Frenchmen is "cheap", my daiquiri next Door was 12$ so a girl can't complain about a styrofoam container loaded down with enough food for two of us, and we couldn't even finish the fries. Don't discount the folks cooking up food in the back of stores if you're visiting from out of town. We were pleasantly surprised. In Ohio gas station food aka "roller food" is more likely to send you to the urgent care or the bathroom than not.
name: Frenchmen Grocery & Deli

text:
I went to this restaurant using a voucher provided by TravelZoo, which included one appetizer, two entrees, dessert for two, and a bottle of wine.  For the appetizer I ordered the Crab Cake with dijoun sauce and found it to be heavy on the cheese and not necessarily New Orleans style, very tasty though.  I ordered an additional bowl of turtle soup which was very meaty and quite good.  For the entree I ordered a Double Cut Pork Chop.  I found it to be cooked to my liking (medium) though tough.  The sauce was sweet and delicious.  The other entree, Swordfish Topped with Crabmeat and Cream Sauce, was much better.  My boyfriend said that the fish was prepared very well (not overly cooked) and the sauce was not overstated allowing the flavor of the fish to come through nicely.  The side dish of mashed purple potatoes were excellent and strangely enough tasted like cake.  The dessert of Chocolate Mousse Torte with Chantilly Cream tasted prepackaged and possibly frozen, though the cream was delicious and fresh.

The service was excellent.  Our server, Rebecca, accomidated us nicely with our wine selection by letting us split wines as my boyfriend and I have differing tastes when it comes to wines.  She was attentive without being overly obtrusive.  When asked a question about the cake-tasting potatoes, she got the chef to personally come to our table and field the questions.

Atmosphere was comfortable.  The room was quiet, although there were few diners at the time on a weekday.

Overall, I would return to this restaurant, however there are probably better places to go in this large culinary city.
name: Roux on Orleans

text: After a couple of foul ups in the past, my husband and I decided to give Joe's Cafe in Westwego a FINAL chance. We ordered food to go, plus pastries and donuts. The total order came to over $30. My husband requested that the pastries and donuts be placed in a donut box. The person serving him starting stuffing the bakery items (6 donuts plus 4 pastries) in a styrofoam go box. He told them once again that he would like the donuts and pastries to be placed in a donut box so that they would not get mashed. He was told that there would be a $1 charge for the donut box! My husband got mad and told them to cancel our order. Basically they lost an order over $30 AND a customer over ONE DOLLAR! I wonder if we would have ordered a dozen donuts if they would have stuffed them in a styrofoam go box or in a paper bag or charge an extra $1 for a donut box! Well, Joe's Cafe...you can keep your $1 donut boxes! We will never patronize ANY of your restaurant locations ever again.
name: Joe's Cafe

text:
Roux on Orleans is inside the Bourbon Orleans hotel. As of my visit in November, they were only doing breakfast but it was a fun menu. You could have something distinctly New Orleans, like shrimp and grits, or something 100% breakfast, like eggs and bacon. This side of bacon was worth everything - it was amazingly crispy with a low amount of grease. I would have taken a to go box as a snack. The local grilled bread was interesting because it was more of a French or Italian bread with garlic on top. The side of local pastries were also very good but you need to like lemon.
The best part were the waitresses - they are a well oiled machine, and on top of that kind and accommodating.
name: Roux on Orleans

text:
We were staying at the Bourbon Orleans and had a couple vouchers for free breakfast, it turns out was for the buffet.

They have a great spread and Tim was a fabulous server. So cool. The first day I got lots of smoked salmon and their egg bake was divine, especially the homemade salsa! Amazing!

The second day I had more egg bake and a fabulous crawfish gumbo. Tim brought out some fresh squeezed OJ, I haven't had that in years. Sooooo good. Also, crazy good.  If I were paying $20 for it, way expensive, but for some vouchers and a tip, this was awesome.

text: We stopped to eat breakfast here on our way to a swamp tour. It doesn't look like much from the outside but the service was good and the food was good. The apple fritter I had was fresh and so yummy! One of the best apple fritters I've ever had. My son and I split the chicken and waffles and my husband had an omelette. Don't let the outside deceive you, give it a try!
name: Joe's Cafe

text:
Westwego's hidden gem! 

It's the perfect little breakfast spot with over the top amazing Danish , pastries and doughnuts. They even have Crawfish and shrimp egg rolls. 

The service is friendly, fast and accurate. It's clean and new! 

It's one of those places where the locals hang out and you better bring hip waiders cause the old men's stories will have you laughing. 

It's only 15 minutes or so from the French Quarter and you will pass swamp tours and airboat rides and minutes from Westwego's famous "shrimp lot" so stop there afterwards.
name: Joe's Cafe

text: We've come to have dinner here before and the food & service are always great....BUT, tonight my husband was wearing his black fedora. As soon as the manager saw him he got motioned to the hostess to ask my husband to please remove the hat. We thought nothing of it since we're sure it's just policy since this is a nicer restaurant. A while later a black gentleman walked in with a hat on. He was asked to remove his hat, but apparently you can refuse to take your hat off in this establishment. What's the point of having a policy if you're not going to enforce it. Doug the manager just didn't want to fuss with the black gentleman so he allowed him to keep his head on.
name: Centroamericana Restaurant

text: La Cocinita is in the Pythian market and I love to come to this "cafeteria" for happy hour for drinks and food with coworkers and friends. I got the three tacos here for only 2 bucks each, which was a great deal for very tender, juicy meat along with the sauces, service is pretty quick and you can come here for lunch or dinner. The only quip about this place (Pythian) in general is that there's no place to hide. So not the best place for a date

text:
I've been here many times already. The food is ON POINT!! Really modern infusions along with some traditional items. My only complaint is the kitchen is extremely slow with pushing the food out. It won't stop me from going. Just be forewarned that you can't go here if you're in a rush, be prepared to wait. BUT it is worth it. I promise. The staff is always friendly. One more thing I feel I have to note, I find that there is a bit too much foul language being used by the staff. I do NOT like that. If you have small children, be forewarned.

Bottom line:
-Excellent food
-Great service
-Slow kitchen
name: Parish Diner

categories: Italian, Breakfast & Brunch, Restaurants, Cajun/Creole, Tex-Mex

text:
My husband and I went to El Paso to eat in Florida for the first time so when the Kenner location opened we both were absolutely thrilled. The restaurant is enormous, pretty, nice colorful! The music was a little too loud for my liking despite my request to lower it down but fortunately it faded as more people entered the restaurant. Our waitress was Ellen, whom was very attentive and was very customer service friendly. Food was very good, it wasnt too bad of a wait considering how many people were dining in that night but our drinks took a little longer than expected (probably because the barmaid with dark hair and glasses was on her cellular phone most of the time) Whoever the shorter male employee is that brought us our food looked almost mad the entire time I saw him walk into dining room and just tossed our hot plates of food on our table in a matter of seconds after mumbling something we didnt understand when he came to our table. I did return to El Paso a handful of other times, once alone, once with the mayor, and another with a party of 5 asking for either Ellen or Nellie but was given a guy whom I forgot his name but remembered it was that same guy who looked mad the first time my husband and I came to eat!!! So it turns out he is also part of management. So how do you distinguish when your a waiter and then part of management? (My husband was so curious he asked another waitress whom I think was named Monique, or Monica) if that was a reoccurring thing and she confirmed it was and stated her concern. Isn't that taking away your staff from making money? And is this manager on a salary and receiving tips? So he is serving tables everyday for lunch and dinner. Then, Great service, delicious food but lastly the one thing that I did not like was the way the manager on duty was speaking to our waitress with such disrespect. Come to find out its because she has been asking for more shifts and has been asking for weeks and he will not allow it but will allow everyone else to work, including one of the actual managers?? Is that even legal? Our advice to her, document everything!!! time, date, record who and what and the issue . I watched the way he was communicating with all his staff, and clearly saw how he was with her individually which I found very hurtful and actually very sad. If it continues, its definetly an issue for the higher up to address and handle possibly? Owner? Labor Board? Lawyer? Your local news outlet? The management clearly is inexperienced and doesn't care about treating ALL their employees FAIRLY and with respect .
We, the paying customers, the patrons, are filling your chairs and booths up come there to eat and enjoy ourselves, sometimes have a drink, enjoy a good meal, but in no way shape or form to feel embarrassed or feel heartbroken for another individual whom you can clearly see getting the short end of the stick for continuing to ask, to beg her boss over and over again to work. Or even pick up anyone's shift who can't make it to work. Neither me, our mayor or anyone can understand how a boss denies giving work to an employee that's desperately wanting to work and support her family doing an excellent job, and is a hard working mom as it is. Those are the employees you want on your team, not turn down and treat like garbage. We were very sad to leave tonight knowing her boss did that to her and or anyone else he's doing too. Anyone who's eaten here, I would make a generous bet, that they have seen how some people are being treated unfairly and lacks professionalism. Whether its dine in or to go. This food rating had snowballed into a whole other issue. Ending this restaurant review rant here, but seriously now I need to follow up with this issue as I now have only sparked growing concern and outcry for these men and women who are working for $2 and some change an hour plus tips that they have to share with the bar person and the person cleaning tables. And here's an extra tip for you ladies, at many of the local businesses that are all over downtown New Orleans and all through the city, Its mandatory for females to have those fake nails cut to a certain length. And thats the restaurants and bars that still allow females to wear those fake things at work.
Do you know how much bacteria and nastiness gets stuck under people's nails? Especially working with food, and almost all the girls had long fake nails and waiting tables. Not all, but MOST.  I dont think anyone is coming to dine in for some tacos, a Michelob draft and a side of nails with some xtra queso. That's just gross. Yuck!!
 Respect everyone! Peace&Love&Harmony 
Judith S. McDonald
name: El Paso Mexican Grill

categories: Restaurants, Latin American, Event Planning & Services, Venezuelan, Caterers, Mexican

text: Without a doubt, this is superb Mexican food in a clean, family-friendly environment with excellent service. The homemade salsa was great with a little heat. The tortilla chips were thin and crispy, yet held the salsa. We ordered a large Queso with Beef.  Lots of seasoned beef in a rich queso. The El Paso Enchiladas consists of three chicken enchiladas, covered in red, green or queso sauce.  I went with queso.  These are the best enchiladas ever!  The chicken is seasoned perfectly, it's moist and deserves to be savored!  The Charro Beans are homemade. Tasted like they had been simmering all day. Awesome flavor!  Served with delicious yellow rice and a side salad, and only $14, you will leave satisfied.  Luis, the manager, came by to check on us twice. But the star of the show was our waiter. Gustavo was thorough, accurate and fast!  Saturday nights they have an amazing Cuban band which only adds flavor to the El Paso experience.  Bring the family!!
name: El Paso Mexican Grill

text:
Food: 5/5
- Build-Your-Own veggie bowl was DELICIOUS, especially the maduros on top. My meal totaled 19$, including a drink so it's a bit pricey, but i'd buy the bowl again in a heartbeat. 
- They have a few different meatless options! 

Drink: 0/5 
- I ordered the horchata, but it turned out to be just plain milk poured over ice. With a sprinkle of cinnamon on top. WHAT? I'm offended. My grandmother is turning in her grave. That's not horchata. That's not even close. 

Location: 3/5 
- Pythian Market (PM) is fresh, roomy, and not too loud/crowded even during lunch hours. 
- I was there to watch a World Cup game because PM advertised themselves as a venue to do so, but their tv's went out every 5-10 minutes and made it impossible to watch. Customers ended up crowding around each other's phones and tvs. If i wanted that, I would've stayed home. 
- Parking can be a hassle in this area. 
- Gentrification.
name: La Cocinita

text:
I went here several months ago and found porky perfection. I returned this morning and got a plateful of fatty garbage
    This illustrates a problem I've found with the type of restaurant that looks like a rat trap   Sometimes you may get something really good but  if you keep coming you are sure to get something really bad. I won't be back again and don't  you go either unless you're feeling lucky.  Mucho sucio, too!
name: Centroamericana Restaurant

attributes.Ambience: {'touristy': False, 'hipster': None, 'romantic': None, 'divey': None, 'intimate': None, 'trendy': False, 'upscale': None, 'classy': False, 'casual': True}

text: My family is originally from Panama and whenever we want to eat Latin food that feels like homecooked we come here! One of my #1 reasons is to drink agua fe guanabana which you can barely even get it much in Panama now a days. Its one of those childhood 'chichas' that never gets old. The food is also really good- the pupusas, el plato centroamericano que trae de todo, las chuletas, los maduros etc. You can't go wrong!! Service is def not 5 stars, maybe 3.5? but I've learned to be patient in life and go with the flow, so when you come eat here just be patient and try not to be starving.  Will def be back!!!
name: Centroamericana Restaurant

text:
I am so glad that La Cocinita has its own page on Yelp instead of just being bundled up with Pythian Market because! I love Pythian market so so much but our experience at La Cocinita was straight up terrible.

We ordered Pork tacos and build your own bowl. 
1. Price/Portion: La cocinita is the only vendor at Pythian Market that I feel like it is truly over-priced. Three tiny tacos (absolutely smaller than tacos around the city) for $10? $11 for Build your own bowl, which is almost like taco salad or bowl in other establishment but a lot smaller, served in a red check paper tray that usually comes with when you order a hot dog on a street... 

2. Service: I give zero stars for this category without hesitation. We ordered at La Cocinita first, then browsed around other vendors, ended up ordering a Poke bowl, paid and received my order from Kais and came back to La cocinita and yet! not ready. Our order came out after a while but everything was wrong. As the name clearly states, it is "Build your OWN bowl" yet bunch of stuff we did not ask for was loaded. A lady next to us was waiting forever and apparently they sold out of something from the sampler she ordered and notified that to her when they brought out her order haha... (Why did you even sell it to her if you sold out!) 

3. Taste wise, it was alright according to the people who ate but nothing spectacular at all.

I come to Pythian Market a lot like over 3 times a week and have not had any bad experience until last Friday. I think it was just that day that was problematic because it was apparent that the lady working behind the counter was not very aware of what was going on and messed up bunch of orders. The cook quickly realized the issues and fixed people's order but yeah, it was not a pleasant experience. I probably will give it a try one more time and might update the review but hey, two stars for now.
name: La Cocinita

text: I was really excited to go to Pythian Market when I saw the list of vendors, and I decided on La Cocinita since I've been to the restaurant before and their food is good. Well, this experience was extremely not. I ordered two orders of tacos and an order of the chips and guacamole ($$$). The two female workers seemed pretty busy cleaning literally everything so I thought maybe they were just opening... at 1:00 in the afternoon on a busy Saturday. So I placed my order and sat in an area close by so I could hear my order called. About 25 minutes pass and I haven't heard anything so I go up to the counter where one person is waiting in line to give put their order in. The two female workers are still cleaning every single surface and haven't acknowledged either of us. I finally get their attention and ask about my order and I'm met with a "Oh, that order. No, it's not ready." So I say okay, and decide to wait at the counter. The two women then become extremely busy cleaning what looks like a drink machine. There are three food order tickets hanging up but they are still wiping out this drink machine and keep taking the containers off and putting them back on. I guess they decided then that it would be a good time to fix the food since someone was standing there. It took them literally 15 minutes to cook the food and assemble three orders. So about 40+ minutes later after I placed my order I got to finally eat some tacos. Tacos were good, but I won't be coming back to this location for them. Also really curious what was in that drink machine - if you have any insight LMK.
name: La Cocinita

text: Stay away from this place! Im central American and THIS FOOD and restaurant is an unworthy place to go. The restaurant gave me a bad impression, after using the restroom I really wanted to get the hell out of there. My friends and I weren't really hungry, therefore I just asked for one plate of food. The owner was sitting right by the bar really near us, and when he realized we just ordered one entree he said; "If it was me I wold be really ashamed of JUST ordering one plate". After my flavorless and uncomfortable meal I paid the check and left more than the 15% Tip, and asked to talk to him. He said he wasn't even talking to us, but then said he perhaps wanted us to hear him. I was calm, trying to explain it was an unnecessary comment. He never apologized, he was stubborn, and very disrespectful. His last words were; "F.... U".... Enough said.... no one should be treated like this, specially by the OWNER of the restaurant. Very disgusting experience.
name: Centroamericana Restaurant

This was a fantastic find! We hit up the Pythian Market close to our hotel and this food hall didn't disappoint. La Cocinita is right in the center of the food hall. 

My husband got the pulled pork tacos (right of photo) and they were delicious! Fresh and bright veggies and wonderful flavor. 

I got the El Pabellon Arepas and they were just mouthwatering. The sweetness of the plantains matched perfectly with the savory beef. 

Amazing filling meal for a super affordable price. A must try!

text: I worked with Keller and then Rachel from La Cocinita to cater my wedding on New Years Eve. From start to finish, I was extremely happy with the service provided. Keller arranged for my wife and I to have a tasting of anything we wanted and discussed all the details for feeding people at the wedding. Closer to the date, Rachel and I hashed out the final food order and delivery. Day of the wedding, the delivery man was exactly on time and the food was amazing. Every guest at the wedding raves about the food, and I personally ate on it for days. I also should mention that the price for the generous portions of delicious food, great service, and timely delivery, was very reasonable. I highly recommend La Cocinita for both catered events or evenings out for dinner. Thanks Keller, Rachel, and everyone at La Cocinita for helping make my wedding very memorable.
name: La Cocinita

text: If you want COLD food and small portions via delivery service, this is the place. Take this review from a regular customer to your veterans highway location: the food arrived at the expected time via DoorDash (no issues there) the tortillas AND the damn chips that came in this were perfectly hot but the main dish, "mixed fajitas" were COLD. Clearly, they sent me food they have been sitting there waiting to be picked up. To make matters worse, the small portion of fajitas which pale in comparison to what you normally get when you're there, we're dancing around in the 8 inch container they packed it. This was horrible, cold food and very small portions isn't what I wanted tonight. I will never order from this place. I worked a double today and was left with no choice but to either eat it or drive this crap back to the restaurant which would've caused a scene for the staff. Learn your business and take care of your customers.
name: El Paso Mexican Grill

text:
First off, I'm really happy to have another Chinese restaurant in the French Quarter. And, based on what I witnessed this weekend, Zhang is off to a very busy and successful start. I'm glad!

This review is based off my experience with take out. I haven't eaten at the restaurant, although the design and decor of the physical space are really appealing. They did a good job revamping the space, which used to be grungy. 

During a busy weekend dinner, the restaurant was very busy. There were a LOT of families and kids, which is not something I'm looking for in a dining experience. My takeout order was also 15 minutes late, which is not a huge deal--especially for a new business. They're still working out the kinks. 

Onto the food. None of the food was bad. My main gripe is that the items I ordered did not match their descriptions on the menu. I ordered vegetable fried rice. However, it didn't come with any vegetables. It did come with tofu, which I did not order. I will say that their tofu is outstanding--much, much better than the tofu I've had at other local Chinese or Thai restaurants. So I wasn't mad about that, but I really missed the vegetables. When ordering (and paying for) vegetables in a dish like fried rice, that means things like broccoli, baby corn, etc. This dish didn't have anything like that. Only tofu. So, while it was basically tasty, that's not something I would have ordered had the description been accurate. I also got medium heat (out of three heat options), and it was not spicy. So, if you're really into heat, I would go with "hot." 

I also got the egg drop soup, which was delicious--easily the best item I ordered. However, the menu says it has peas, carrots, and mushroom. It didn't have any of these things. It's important that menu items are accurate and that the kitchen is in communication with front of house on this sort of thing. This might all fall under the "working out the kinks" umbrella. 

I also tried the "spicy" cucumber salad, though it was not spicy at all. It was more of a sweet, soy-based sauce. It was fine. The veggie egg rolls were standard, in the Thai style. For a to go order, the presentation was nice. The egg rolls had a slice of lemon and an attractive sprig of mint. I appreciated the presentation. I imagine the presentation in the restaurant must be very nice. 

I'll definitely be back in a few weeks to try other dishes and see how things have progressed. Overall, a very welcome addition to the French Quarter.
name: Zhang Bistro

text: Woke up this morning thinking about how delicious dinner was last night. My friend and I ate outside along Magazine St. I kept it simple with the Red Gravy over homemade pasta. Our waiter, Will, was very friendly and attentive. My friend has dietary restrictions and he helped her chose an amazing Chicken Marsala with seasoned mashed potatoes. The fresh mozzarella added the perfect amount of saltiness as the Red Gravy is slightly sweet. I had all the toasted bread to myself because of my friend's dietary restrictions and used every piece to dip in both my red gravy and her Marsala. Even the next table over commented on how much we enjoyed our meal. Can't wait to go back.

text: The empanadas trio is an appetizer, but it was plenty of food, especially if you are seeking to try some other vendors in Pythian. I started with the chicken, and they had me hooked, especially with the two sauces provided. Both are creamy and did not taste spicy, so I'm not entirely sure what the difference was. Just know, it was good. Then I bit into the pork. This had a bit of a kick to it. At this point the chicken was getting my bite for number one. Don't get me wrong though, the pork was still tasty and left no regrets. The last on the tasting list was cheese. Now I love cheese. And this empanada had ooey gooey tasty cheese that bumped it up to the number one flavor! Next time I would probably do the trip again, but only get cheese and chicken. And an order of the plantains!

The El PabellÃ³n is filled with shredded beef, and that beef is very well seasoned. The bread holding the arepa together is sort of toasted. It's a little softer on the inside. text:
I was so happy when this restaurant came to our neighborhood! I don't usually write reviews of this nature, but the owner of this place needs to be aware of the actions of their hostess, the "face" of the restaurant. I have to say that I was VERY disappointed with the reception we received from the hostess "Mike" this past Saturday nite, around 6:50pm. Having dined here before, we had never encountered "Mike" or her unique way of treating perspective diners. 
We arrived and inquired if outdoor seating was available. We had no reservations. The indoor dining room was empty. The hostess informed us that the rear courtyard was full, but a table on the front sidewalk had just become available. We replied that was great, " perfect we would take it". Then the hostess quickly replied, " wait, oh, we have a large party (12) coming in so that table really needs to stay empty, next time you should make a reservation".

Having dined here 4 times since they reopened at this uptown location (Uptown restaurants thrive or die on their regular locals unlike quarter/CBD establishments which often cater to the infrequently visiting tourists, it is a different dynamic) I was aware that the rear courtyard seats about 16 people, and there were only 2 other diners in the WHOLE restaurant, at best 25 percent capacity at 7 pm on a Saturday night! Besides, we were offered seating outside, at a sidewalk table that was occupied just 30 seconds earlier, hardly a staffing hardship! Hostess "Mike" went on to say, " the kitchen is really small, you should have made a reservation, I am so sorry" with a very affected manner. I had to wonder what would they do if they actually had ANY indoor diners. 

Background; when this place relocated to uptown, I dined there on it's first night. It was EMPTY on that first weekday night. Our meal was very good, we paid and tipped waitress 30%. In addition, I was so glad to see a "new" restaurant attempting to open in our neighborhood I left $100 with the bartender to split with staff on this VERY slow night.  On that first slow night,  and on every slow night since,  the staff was very friendly and helpful. Not tonight with "Mike" the hostess at the helm. This owner's back story, printed on the menu,  promises her fulfillment of a life long dream centered on Italian hospitality and food prepared " a Mano". Our hostess's reception was anything but hospitable, and her refusal to seat us was simply ridiculous. I couldn't believe the owner had left this woman in charge of the "front of house". Accordingly, I asked to speak with the owner having dined/taken out numerous times, and  then it really got inexplicably weird, Mike"  the hostess refused to "bother" the owner! 
"Mike" informed us that she/owner was "really unavailable", yet on the premises in the kitchen. "Mike" said she would not disturb the owner as she was "working". Really?  At this point you could not have paid me to eat, but in this difficult economic environment I could not believe what I was hearing. I hope the owner sees this. Really a shame, we used to love eating here. Good luck,  and good bye y'all.
name: Red Gravy
categories: Restaurants, Pasta Shops, Desserts, Sandwiches, Food, Seafood, Italian, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Specialty Food, Breakfast & Brunch

text: Last Saturday I went to @parishdiner. I ordered Tabasco glaze wings and smoked brisket hash browns, eggs and toast. The smoked brisket was cold in some spots, the hash browns were pretty flavorful and the onions were good. The eggs whites were a little raw. The yolk was perfect. The toast was great. Overall I wouldn't recommend the smoked brisket hash browns. The Tabasco glazed wings. The sauce was a bit underwhelming. I don't feel it had a bold flavor. The wings were way overdone, the meat was tough. There were cold parts of the wing, the skin was a bit crispy. Overall probably one of the worst wings I have eaten. This meal definitely wasn't worth the price.

text:
Rarely do I let my food escape a photo shoot or my friend's food for that matter. I had a lunch meeting at Pythian Market and really enjoyed the mini arepas that La Cocinita had at the media party so I bee-lined it to them to order. 

I have not had carne asada in New Orleans as good as back in Idaho so I was both excited and leery to order the La Llanera - Crispy Arepa with Carne Asada, Guasacaca, Grilled Queso Fresco, Salsa Verde, & Pico de Gallo. You get two arepas with the order. It takes a second, but worth it.

These two arepas were the perfect amount of lunch for me and they hit the spot. The carne asada was thick little well-seasoned chunks of meat and not cheap stringy bits. The mix was no store bought pico. And the arepas...y'all. I'm not a big corn tortilla person and I hate when this sort of dish just crumbles but these were crispy and fluffy at the same time and held it all together 'til my last bite! 

So my deepest apologies for no pictures but there's always a next time, especially here!
name: La Cocinita

text:
I'm not able to review the food, but service was horrendous. Our party of four (2 adults and 2 kids) walked in as another party left. We saw there was one waitress working with one table of two, two tables of four (one had just been seated), and a large party that was seated at two joined tables. Two tables still had to be cleared, and one table was free. (There was a lot of time to make observations.) At one point the waitress acknowledged us and said she would be right with us. She went into the kitchen one or two times. And then she stopped at one of the tables of four and took their order - before seating us. A couple came in during this time. The waitress then seated us and gave us menus and silverware. She cleaned a table and seated the couple. We waited. She cleaned the second dirty table. She returned to the kitchen. She brought frosty fruit drinks to the table that had ordered while we had waited at the front. She then took the order of the couple who had come in five minutes after us. At that point we decided to leave. 

Maybe takeout is the way to go.
name: Golden Gate Bistro

text: We had a horrible experience tonight.  I have an allergy to tomato seeds. I order three chicken tacos with lettuce, onions, and cheese.  I reiterated the no tomatoes to my waiter. When my food came out there were tomatoes all over the tacos.  I called the waiter back over and he brought them back to the kitchen.  Mean while we order two margaritas which took 20 minutes to show up to the table and were not frozen anymore.  Had to send them back. Meanwhile my tacos show back up at the table. Guess what the people in the kitchen just removed the tomatoes and did not remake the tacos.  Since I am allergic I had to send them back again.  My daughter ordered chicken quesadillas and was brought ground beef.  Had to send them back.  Finally after about thirty minutes the tacos show up made correctly.  We receive the bill and I see that I have been charged for the tacos and an up charge of 2.25 for onions.  I ask to speak with the manager.  The manager came over and I asked him to remove the tacos from the bill.  He proceeded to ask me why.  So I told him why.   This is the last time I will visit this restaurant.  The manager lost a customer plus his server did not receive a tip on a 10 top.  Bad customer service and the staff needs to learn how to speak English.
name: El Paso Mexican Grill

text:
Having gone here 3x now I thought I'd give my experience. We tried this place because the location by the same name in Baton Rouge is hands down the best spot for Mexican food. For some reason the times we've gone here have been on a Tuesday. And every time "Elvis" has been singing. Lots of older people sitting and clapping. 
The food is okay, nothing to rave about. The steak with my fajitas was tough. And the portions are smaller than what we've come to expect. 
The waitress was very nice and the margaritas have kick so hence the 3 stars.  Maybe I'll go on another night to compare.
name: El Paso Mexican Grill

text: We tried Golden Gate Bistro for the first time and absolutely fell in love! It is tucked inside Colmex Construction building on Earhart and a bit easy to miss the first time around. We tried the pork chops and the Patacon Gloria - both were incredible! I'm not usually a big fan of friend green plantains, but I couldn't stop eating the ones here! SO GOOD! I can't wait to come back when I'm extra hungry to try the Bandeja Paisa. I haven't had it since I lived in Colombia over a decade ago, but from this experience I'm very optimistic that this place will do it right. Can't wait to be back!
name: Golden Gate Bistro

text: We ordered take out from Golden Gate Bistro for dinner. We were super excited based on the menu (and prices). Ordering over the phone was very quick and easy (35 minute pick up time - so we knew everything would be made to order). We ordered 2 grilled chicken plates with tostones and sweet plantains, they also came with salads and rice. We also ordered a beef empanada. Everything was so fresh and flavorful. We'll definitely be back!
name: Golden Gate Bistro

text: I've been dying to go to El Paso since I've been back home because it's one of my favorite Mexican restaurants, so I'm so so glad I got to go there for lunch today! I ordered the chicken fajitas with their charro bean soup and it was amazing. I will say, they did skimp a little on the chicken. I noticed there were way more onions and bell peppers than chicken, BUT I was still extremely full after my meal. I do believe they should give you more since their lunch fajitas were about $14. Nonetheless, I will continue to go back here because I love the atmosphere and their food is just so damn good. I also would like to note that I've been to the El Paso on Veterans in Metairie and it is just not as good as the one on West Esplanade. The atmosphere at the Kenner one is so lively and fun and their quality is just amazing, so I would definitely recommend the one on West Esplanade. The service was excellent, as always, and our complimentary chip baskets were never empty. Cannot wait to go back next time I'm in town!
name: El Paso Mexican Grill
